text: Right now, I’m at Lake Michigan on vacation.

Well, not right now, my right now but your
right now as you see this.

In fact, I’m so busy relaxing that I couldn’t
make a video this week but I thought ahead

and I created a mashup 2 videos from past
vacations where I teach English to you with

my friends and family in beautiful Michigan
on vacation.

So won’t you please come on vacation with
me and study English pronunciation, conversation

Uncle Frank brings his boat every year so
that we can try skiing.

Did you notice the reductions of the word
“that” and “can”?
These two function words will often reduce.

“That” becomes thut, with either a flap
or a stop T, depending on the next sound.

And “can”, when not the main verb in the
sentence, becomes kn, kn.
So that we can try skiing.

“Try” and “skiing”, the two content
words in this sentence, are clearly much longer

These four function words are low in pitch
and very fast.
So that we can try skiing.
>> Well, I’m glad to bring it.

Here, Frank reduced the word ‘to’ to the
flap T and the schwa sound: de, de, de, glad
>> Well, I’m glad to bring it.

This boat is 17 years old, and I was beginning
to wonder earlier in the week if I was going

Here Frank reduced the phrase “going to”
to “gonna”.
A very common reduction in American English.
If I was going to bring it back, gonna, gonna.
If I was going to bring it back.

>> I was beginning to wonder earlier in the
week
if I was going to bring it back again,

but it seems like people are still kind of
interested in skiing, so.

Did you hear how I connected the V sound to
the word it?

One of the easiest ways to link in American
English pronunciation, is the case when one

word ends in a consonant and the next word
begins with a vowel or diphthong.

You can practice the connection between words
by putting the ending consonant on the next

word: vit, vit, vit, love it, love it, love
it.
This will help to eliminate gaps between words.

In American English, we want to link all the
words in one thought group.

>> We’ll see if it’ll go a couple more
years.
>> So Jace, you going to go skiing today?
>> You going to go skiing today?

>> It might take a couple tries, so don’t
be discouraged if it doesn’t happen right

Did you notice how I linked the ending T of
‘right’ to the beginning vowel sound of

This means that the T comes between two vowels,
so it becomes a flap T, or, a D sound.

So, ‘right away’ sounds just like ‘ride
away’.
>> If it doesn’t happen right away.
>> Meg, are you going to try skiing?

Also notice, I’ve reduced the word ‘are’
to er, er, er.
>> Meg, are you going to try skiing?

I tried it when I was ten, and I was traumatized
because I fell, and it hurt.

>> So, I think I’m just going to stick to
a bystander.

>> I’ve done sit skiing before, when I was,
like, six.

Just like with “right away”, we’re connecting
the ending T in “what” to the beginning
So the T turns into a flap T, or D sound.

>> And there’s a chair in the middle and
you just sit.
>> I’ve never even heard of that.

Another linking consonant to vowel heard of,
heard of.

Notice that I am reducing the word “of”
to the schwa-V sound: uv, uv, duv, duv, heard of.
>> I’ve never even heard of that.

Another great example of linking ending consonant
to beginning vowel.
So, I’m nervous to do this.
>> I think you’ll be just fine.

Here, Haley reduced the contraction “I’m”,
to simply the M consonant.

Of course, with that reduction, she linked
it to the next word, mmready.
>> Brooke, how are you enjoying your vacation?
>> I’m having a great time on my vacation.

>> What’s the highlight of your vacation
so far?

>> I think the highlight of vacation so far
is spending time with you, Rachel.
>> Ani, did you make that necklace?
>> Can you hold it up for me?

Another reduction of ‘can’: kn, can you,
can you.
>> Can you hold it up for me?
A reduction of ‘it’s’ to the TS sound.
Have you ever heard someone say “lemme”?

I’ve dropped the T in ‘let’, and connected
it to ‘me’.
Let me, let me, let me see that.
It has those gg sounds, and a dark L. Giggle.
>> We’re doing a little advertising, yeah.
>> Hey, Rach, I love that shirt.
Linking ending consonant to beginning vowel.

>> It says ‘I love English’ in the International
Phonetic Alphabet.
>> Oh my gosh, that’s so great.
>> Actually, you can get one right here.

>> Yeah, do you want to be on my website,
Brad?

Here, I use the “wanna” reduction for
“want to”.

>> Yeah, do you want to be on my website,
Brad?
Here, Brad reduced “kind of” to kinda.

So the word “of” is pronounced with just
the schwa, no consonant sound.

>> Brad, B-R-A-D, it has the aa as in bat
vowel.

And remember, cousin: spelled with an S, pronounced,
zz, like a Z.

Here, we’ll all tell the score keeper if
we made our bet or not.

Listen for how we all link those two words
together, made it, no gap.
>> Uncle Dale, did you make that fire?
>> Hey everybody, this is my uncle Dale.

I hope that even with just these few snippets
of conversation, you’ve learned a bit about
linking consonant to vowel and reductions.

They’re an important part to the smoothness
and the rhythm of American English.

And as you can see, they’re used all the
time in conversation.

Special thanks to my family for letting me
video tape our vacation, and if you didn’t
We’re all getting together again at Christmas.

Every year, my extended family gets together
for a week to play, swim, and have fun together.
First, let’s head to the beach.
– Except for you got a face full of water?

Let’s talk about the phrase ‘except for’,
it’s pretty common.

The T comes between two consonant sounds,
and in that case, natives often drop the T
Except for– Just the P then the F, excep’for.
Also, notice that I reduced the word ‘for’.
Except for– Except for you got.

– Well, it got my no [nose!], that I, I
start
Well this is the perfect day for him.
How did my mom pronounce the word “and”?
Well this is the perfect day for him.

This is how it’s normally pronounced, unless
you want to stress the word ‘and’.
What about standing up like Gigi?

Check this out: she can pull hair and stand
up at the same time.

She can pull hair and stand up at the same
time.

Most of the time, you’ll want to reduce
this, nn, just like my mom.

We reduce ‘can’ when it’s a helping
verb, that is, not the main verb in the sentence.

Most of the time, ‘can’ is a helping verb:
kn, kn.

On this day, it happened to be Gina’s first
birthday.
We sang happy birthday to her.

Not quite as good as Marlise’s, but not
bad.
We use this phrase a lot.
It means okay, but not great.
What do you notice about the pronunciation?

That’s a Flap T. Not a True T, pretty, but
a Flap T, pretty.
This is the American English pronunciation.

I write it with a D, but depending on your
native language, it may sound like an R to

Just flap the tongue against the roof of the
mouth without stopping the air.
Pretty good, with the UH as in PUSH vowel.
My uncle makes it very clear.
See if you can imitate him.
You wanna go watch the tennis game?
You want to go watch the tennis game?
My family loves to play tennis on vacation.
Very few of us are any good at it.
These are the fans out for the big match.

Did you notice how my dad reduced the word
“are”?

This is how we pronounce ARE, it just sounds
like an extra syllable at the end of the word
Don’t go easy on him, Ernie.
What do you notice about the word “him”?
No H. We pronounce “him” this way a lot.

Just like “are”, when it’s reduced,
think of adding an extra syllable to the end
Don’t go easy on him, Ernie.
Let me go check on him.
Here’s another HIM reduction: Check on him.
On him, on him, on him.
Um, wait, when did you meet Gigi in Colorado?

Did you, would you, could you, should you:
all common two-word phrases.

We often make the Y sound a J sound when it
comes after a D. Diijew, jj, jj, jj.
– Uh, we were out there to ski in March.
Anybody want to hit a few with my partner?
Did you hear that in the background?
Anybody want to hit a few
That’s what she thinks of your hat.

You’ll notice that we sometimes drop the
V sound in ‘of’; we just use the schwa.
Thinks of, thinks of your hat.
– Oh, don’t whack her in the head.

– Don’t let him put his mouth on that,
Dad.
Don’t whack her in the head.
Did you notice the dropped H in ‘her’?
Don’t whack her in the head.
Man, it’s such a nice evening.

Perfect temperature, slight breeze, beautiful
sun.
Listen to how I talk about the weather:
Man, it’s such a nice evening.

Perfect temperature, slight breeze, beautiful
sun.
Notice I only make one T. Perfect temperature.

So you can think of dropping the T in “perfect”,
because you have one beginning the next word.

Also, I make “temperature” just three
syllables: TEM-per-chur.

I made the T in ‘slight’ a stop T because
the next word begins with a consonant.

The T in ‘beautiful’ is a Flap T because
it comes between two vowels.
Man, it’s such a nice evening.

Perfect temperature, slight breeze, beautiful
sun.
Going out might be sort of fun.

Except for that I don’t want to have to
go forever.
Did you hear that phrase again?

I reduced “except” to just “sep”,
without releasing the p.

I also reduced “for” and “that” – “that”
had the schwa and a Stop T. Sep-fer-thut.
I don’t want to have to go forever.
– I don’t want to have to drive very far.
Is he messing up your coloring, Lydia?

My aunt is dropping the TH in them, tell um,
tell um.

This sounds just like ‘him’ when the H
is dropped, um, um.
They sound the same when they’re reduced.
When I get tired, this is how I end.
David is a little less graceful.

What I fun week I had with my family playing
games, swimming.
They’re special people, and I can’t wait
